Headline.Para: Congress Reaches Deal to Fix Tax Overhaul's 'Grain Glitch'; Provision that helped farm cooperatives and hurt their corporate competitors is expected to be attached to must-pass spending bill

LeadPara.Para: WASHINGTONâ€”U.S. lawmakers reached a last-minute deal to reverse an error in December's tax law that was helping farm cooperatives and hurting their corporate competitors.
The agreement to alter the so-called grain glitch is attached to a must-pass spending bill slated to become law later this week, and the details were released late Wednesday.

TailParas.Para: Democrats, who had been wary of helping Republicans change the tax law without extracting a concession, won an expansion of the low-income housing tax credit in exchange.
Congress is now set to make the first significant change to the
tax code overhaul Republicans muscled through Washington last year. The bill also includes $320 million for the Internal Revenue Service to implement the new law.

The coop provision may be the exception rather than the rule for future changes to the GOP tax law, because members of both parties representing agricultural states were eager for quick action. Alternatively, this week's trade could become a precedent, showing a path where Republicans can make the corrections they need and Democrats can achieve some of their own priorities.

Under the tax law passed in December, farmers who sell grain and other products to cooperatives get a much larger deduction than if they sell to a private or investor-owned company, because they could deduct 20% of gross sales instead of 20% of net income. In some cases, farmers could wipe out their entire taxable income.

The provision's authors, including Sens. John Hoeven (R., N.D.) and John Thune (R., S.D.), were trying to make sure that cooperatives and their patrons benefited from the 20% deduction available to other pass-through businesses.

They said the significant advantage given to cooperatives was inadvertent, and lawmakers have been working on a potential change since January. Without a change, independent grain elevators were worried about business drying up, and companies were considering creating their own cooperatives.
"That's a critical area, and it needs to be cleaned up," said Sen. Mike Rounds (R., S.D.) "It was a mistake that was made, and it has to be corrected."

Republicans reached an agreement with industry groups representing cooperatives and companies including Cargill Inc. and Archer Daniels Midland Co. Top tax legislators from the House and Senate signed on.

If the fix is passed as part of the spending bill, "it'll be a huge relief," said Todd Lafferty, co-chief executive of Wheeler Brothers Grain Co. Time has been running short for the Oklahoma-based grain company, which buys wheat from farmers at locations around the state. About 90% of the millions of bushels of grain the company buys and trades each year is winter wheat, and with that crop's harvest approaching at the beginning of June, farmers soon will begin to sell it, Mr. Lafferty said. If the new U.S. tax law continues to provide big benefits for farmers who sell their crops to cooperatives, Wheeler Brothers stands to lose out on a significant part of its annual business, Mr. Lafferty said.

The proposal would cap farmers' deduction at 20% of net income, excluding capital gains. Farmers could also get an additional benefit from deductions at cooperatives where they are members. The provision is generally retroactive to the beginning of 2018.
The obstacle came in adding it to the spending bill, which advocates for the provision saw as the best chance for the measure to advance.

The tax law passed under congressional procedures that allowed for a simple-majority vote in the Senate. The spending bill, however, will require at least 60 votes, meaning that Democrats had to be involved.
Senate Democrats sought an expansion of the low-income housing tax credit, and House Republicans initially balked at that price, Mr. Rounds said.

Sen. Maria Cantwell (D., Wash.) sought the housing-credit changes, which would increase part of the program by 12.5%. In part, that policy is also a response to the GOP tax law, which reduced tax rates and thus indirectly made the credit less valuable. It is another sign of Democrats' willingness to make piecemeal policy changes to the tax law rather than campaigning against the entire thing.
"Housing was hurt in the tax bill," Ms. Cantwell said. "If people want to say who was hurt in the tax bill and they want to fix that, we definitely want to do something about housing, that's all."

The negotiations went back and forth repeatedly in the final days, and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) raised late concerns about the effects on specialty crop growers and cooperatives in California and elsewhere. That includes the state's fruit, nut and vegetable industries.
"It's been dead, revived, dead, revived," Mr. Thune said on Tuesday afternoon. "The issue has to be solved, and this is the best place to do it."
The spending bill doesn't make changes to other parts of the 2017 tax law, but it does include technical corrections to tax laws going back to 2004.
Jacob Bunge, Kristina Peterson and Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.
Write to Richard Rubin at richard.rubin@wsj.com
